text: <@U6H9SJKCH> Sorry for the unclear description. I met some obstacles that MvNormal() distribution doesn't accept non-positive definite covariance matrix. I tried some other method to force it to be symmetry and positive definite. However, those methods could not apply to the dual type variables in Turing process. Thus, I want to define a customMvNormal distribtuion which use svd decomposition instead of Cholesky() in the original MvNormal()

elements.text: Sorry for the unclear description. I met some obstacles that MvNormal() distribution doesn't accept non-positive definite covariance matrix. I tried some other method to force it to be symmetry and positive definite. However, those methods could not apply to the dual type variables in Turing process. Thus, I want to define a customMvNormal distribtuion which use svd decomposition instead of Cholesky() in the original MvNormal()

text: There could also be a problem with your model definition.

text: <@U6CFMFM2R> Dear Benjamin, so sorry for a pause. I have just uploaded the minimal question in this channel. Could you help me check with model definition?
